Caption: Figure 1: The interface of FPSSeer: (a) frame rate view to show the overall distribution; (b) grid view to visualize the f ps distribution in a grid element and similarities among grid elements; (c) FootRiver view to depict major migration changes from one gaming condition to another on adjacent time frames; (d) comparison view to quantitatively measure the game performance difference between tests.

Figure 2: (a) frame rate view with grid element size of 5 and sampling threshold of 10; (b) grid element size of 10 and sampling threshold of 10; (c) Player transitions between adjacent time frames representing by moving blue arrows. (d) By selecting an area, the trajectories into this region are represented by green moving arrows while those start from this region are represented by red moving arrows.

Figure 3: Layers represent stable players of whom the gaming con- dition ( f ps level and display setting) are consistent between times- tamps; Threads depict migration changes of gaming condition from one layer to another; Ellipses encode lost players in each timestamp of layers. The whereabouts of players in the layer of sky-blue in time- frame t are: (to layers a, b, d), stable layer (c) and lost players (e).
Figure 4: Sampling numbers are encoded as different colors and the “smoothness” of the f ps distribution is encoded as glyph shape.

Figure 7: Transition trajectories from players’ positions at the pre- vious timestamp to the next positions through clicking the transition threads in the FootRiver view and the corresponding trajectories will be plotted in the frame rate view.

Figure 5: Patterns of AOI(Area of Interest) and the scatter layout of different display settings (level 1,2,3): AOI 1 and AOI 2 have large dif- ference in sampling number. A deviation grid element (AOI 3) shows the lowest fps 1 occupies the highest portion of all its samples.

Figure 6: In deviation grid elements (CP1, CP2), the cumulative per- cent of relatively lower fps values occupies over a portion of 80%. In the main pattern (CP3, CP4), the highest fps value (60) occupies nearly 20% of all samplings.

Figure 11: (a) the frame rate view from the first test; (b) the frame rate view from the second test; (c) performance difference heat map of the two tests; (d) improvement/degradation/ performance (red: degrada- tion, green: improvement, yellow: unchanged) under the standard of 30 fps. (d) the fps distribution in the entrance of this scenarios: 20 fps occupies a large portion.
Figure 10: Display setting transitions fall into two categories: step forward and move backward.

Figure 8: FootRiver view to show the main transitions happened in layer 2-1, 2-2, 1-3, and 2-3. When the fps level is relatively low, and if the corresponding display setting is high (median or high), players will proactively adjust their display settings to a lower level (from layer 1-3, 2-3 to layer 2-1 or 3-1; from 1-3, 2-3 to layer 2-2 or 3-2, etc.).

Figure 9: The grid view can help analysts detect deviation values. The entrance of this scenario demonstrates a different pattern, in which there are relatively more samples than other areas where 1 fps occupying a significant ratio, as indicated by a yellow circle.

Figure 12: Users can interactively refine outliers (remove grid ele- ment 5, and 95) and check up on whether exists significant volatility. If not, then a reliable correlation coefficient is obtained to calculate the final game performance difference.
